data.text: INDEX
Appendix 1: Preliminary Equality Analysis
Purpose

Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust promotes breastfeeding as the healthiest way for a mother to feed her baby and recognises the important health benefits known to exist for both the mother and child.
This guideline is intended to support mothers with hand expressing antenatally to obtain and store colostrum.

This guideline is primarily aimed at mothers who may have a delay or difficulty establishing breastfeeding or in producing breastmilk, and to protect babies who are at risk of hypoglycaemia or feeding difficulties from the risks of formula supplementation. However all women can harvest colostrum antenatally if they wish to do so.
To support initiation, exclusivity and duration of breastfeeding.
To ensure that relevant health care professionals involved in the care of pregnant women are aware of the benefits of antenatal hand expression and safe storage of colostrum.
Objectives
To improve breastfeeding initiation and maintenance in high risk pregnancies.
To maximise breastmilk for all mothers who wish to breastfeed.
To assist women to become comfortable and competent when hand expressing.
To encourage a generous supply of colostrum.
To have colostrum readily available for the baby in the early hours after birth.
To ensure that women who desire to exclusively breastfeed are able to do so.
To ensure that the Trust support the UNICEF BFI standards supplementing with formula milk only when medically necessary.
Equality Impact Assessment
Mid Essex Hospital Services NHS Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
(Refer to Appendix 1)
Definition
Antenatal colostrum harvesting is defined as the hand expression of colostrum by the mother.
Rationale

Colostrum is the optimum source of nutrition for the newborn baby as it is rich in antibodies, has high bioavailability, increases gut peristalsis and aids the passage of meconium. Colostrum also aids in the activation of early protective immunological responses in the infants gut and therefore should be the first food given to infants.

The CEMACH Diabetes programme report recommends exclusive breastfeeding for infants at risk of hypoglycaemia, as breast milk appears to promote ketogenesis and formula supplementation may suppress the process of metabolic adaptation.
All mothers, regardless of any pre-existing conditions should be supported to initiate early and exclusive breastfeeding.

Infants who are at risk of hypoglycaemia in the first few hours after birth are more likely to be given infant formula to stabilise their blood sugar levels while adequate breastfeeding is established . Antenatally expressed colostrum can be very useful to help stabilise the newborn's blood glucose levels and avoid the need for formula supplementation.

Infant formula contains bovine serum albumin which is associated with generating an auto-immune response linked to an increased risk of Type 1 diabetes mellitus particularly where there is a strong family history of diabetes.
Inclusion Criteria
Any woman can express her colostrum antenatally between 36 to 37 weeks gestation.
Women or women expecting babies in the following groups should be encouraged to express colostrum during the antenatal period:
Diabetic in pregnancy (pre-existing or gestational);
Planned elective LSCS (lower segment Caesarean section);
Breast hypoplasia;
Taking Beta-blockers (e.g. Labetalol);
Hormonal disorders (e.g. PCOS, hypothyroidism);
Previous breast surgery;
Multiple sclerosis;
BMI over 37;
Strong family history of dairy intolerance or inflammatory bowel disease;
Diagnosed cleft lip and/or palate;
Congenital conditions (e.g. Trisomy 21);
Twin or triplet pregnancy;
Small for gestational age (SGA);
Contraindications
The antenatal expression of colostrum is contraindicated in the following circumstances:
History of threatened/actual premature labour;
Cervical incompetence;
Cervical suture insitu;
History of antenatal bleeding in this pregnancy.
Diabetic Mothers
Diabetic mothers should be particularly encouraged to express colostrum in the late antenatal period as their babies are at increased risk of developing hypoglycaemia in the first hours after birth.

Babies who are unable to feed after birth or have low blood sugar will require colostrum. If colostrum is not available then it is likely that the baby will be given formula milk which research has demonstrated can trigger an autoimmune response in the infant and increase the risk of the baby subsequently becoming diabetic.

The DAME study found “No harm in advising women with diabetes in pregnancy at low risk of complications to express breastmilk from 36 weeks gestation” and highlighted the benefit such as an increase of exclusive breastfeeding and a reduction in formula supplementation. (2017)
Process

Women should have a discussion about infant feeding with a health professional between 28 and 36 weeks and given a copy of the patient information leaflet “antenatal colostrum harvesting”. The discussion should include the benefit of antenatal colostrum harvesting and the contraindications.
Women who wish to harvest their colostrum should be shown how to hand express using a knitted breast.

A small selection of oral syringes, bungs and sticky labels will be provided. Women should provide a small container to collect the colostrum and a zip lock bag for storing the syringes in the freezer.

Women should be informed that when they attend hospital in labour that they should bring in up to 3-4 syringes of frozen colostrum. It should be stored in a freezer bag with freezer blocks and transferred to the postnatal ward milk fridge on arrival. MEHT are unable to store frozen colostrum on the postnatal ward so milk will need to be used within 24 hours once defrosted. It may be necessary to bring the colostrum to the hospital over a period of days to avoid unnecessary wastage through inability to store safely.
Once in hospital the colostrum should be clearly labelled with mother's name, hospital number and the date it was removed from the freezer.
Technique
How to teach hand expressing and storage of colostrum in the antenatal period:
Highlight the importance of hand hygiene;
Discuss the role of oxytocin and how to stimulate it, e.g. privacy, low lighting massage and warmth;
Using a knitted breast demonstrate breast massage from the chest towards the nipple to encourage oxytocin and the let-down reflex;
The thumb should be placed above the nipple and the fingers below in a “C” shaped grip, 2-3 cm back from the base of the nipple then gently squeeze and release in a regular rhythmic motion;
Once colostrum starts to drip/flow easily the mother can collect it in a clean pot and then draw it up with the provided syringe;
The mother should keep her hands in one position until the milk flow slows. Then she should move her hands around to a different position, ensuring that all lobes are drained;
Once the flow subsides then the second breast should be tried;
This should take around 5-10 minutes.

Colostrum can be collected 2-3 times over a 24 hour period and stored in the same syringe. The syringe should be capped off with a bung and kept in the back of the fridge to a maximum temperature of C.
After 24 hours the syringe containing colostrum should be placed in the freezer in a labelled zip lock bag.
Each syringe should be labelled with the mothers name, hospital number and expressing date.
Expressed colostrum can be stored in the freezer for:
2 weeks in a freezer compartment of a fridge;
3 months in a freezer around -18C;
6 months in the deep freeze below -18C.
Defrosted colostrum should be used or discarded within 24 hours.
Feeding support and advice can be obtained from the Specialist Midwife for Infant Feeding on ext. 3676 or 07887 636741 during the antenatal period or whilst the mother is an inpatient.
Birth
At delivery skin to skin contact should be encouraged with the offer of an early breastfeed.
Good positioning and attachment should be taught and encouraged as soon as possible.

If indicated blood sugar levels should be monitored (refer to guideline 12025 Management of Infants at High Risk of Hypoglycaemia) and fresh or defrosted colostrum should be used to correct any imbalance if the baby will not latch on to the breast.
Mothers should be encouraged to initiate lactation as usual (refer to ‘Management of breastfeeding'; register number 09111) and supported with hand expressing if indicated.
All babies should be managed using the infant feeding care pathway.
Additional Notes

Until the late 1970's all women were encouraged to express colostrum during late pregnancy. This practice was discouraged following concerns that nipple and breast stimulation and the consequent release of oxytocin could lead to premature labour. This theory has not been supported by reliable evidence. The recent DAME RCT (2017) found that antenatal colostrum harvesting did not induce labour in the groups studied.
Nipple stimulation at term may assist with cervical ripening. If done for up to 45 minutes 3 times a day.
Women can and many do breastfeed throughout pregnancy (i.e. feed a toddler).
In recognition that nipple stimulation may cause mild uterine contractions it is recommended that women:
Commence daily expression between 36 and 37 weeks gestation;
Start with 3-5 minutes on each breast;
The total time expressing once proficient should only be 5-10 minutes at each session but can be done more than once a day;
Painless Braxton Hicks are acceptable whilst hand expressing. Advise the woman to stop expressing if the uterine contractions become regular and painful.
Staffing and Training
All midwifery and obstetric staff must attend yearly mandatory training which includes skills and drills training.
All midwifery and obstetric staff are to ensure that their knowledge and skills are Up-to-date in order to complete their portfolio for appraisal.
Infection Prevention
All staff should follow Trust guidelines on infection prevention by ensuring that they effectively ‘decontaminate their hands' before and after each procedure.
All maternity staff should be aware of the methods for sterilising equipment.
Mothers should be advised of the importance of sterilising any infant feeding equipment.
Audit and Monitoring

Audit of compliance with this guideline will be considered on an annual audit basis in accordance with the Clinical Audit Strategy and Policy (register number 08076), the Corporate Clinical Audit and Quality Improvement Project Plan and the Maternity annual audit work plan; to encompass national and local audit and clinical governance identifying key harm themes. The Women's and Children's Clinical Audit Group will identify a lead for the audit.

The findings of the audit will be reported to and approved by the Multi-disciplinary Risk Management Group (MRMG) and an action plan with named leads and timescales will be developed to address any identified deficiencies. Performance against the action plan will be monitored by this group at subsequent meetings.
The audit report will be reported to the monthly Directorate Governance Meeting (DGM) and significant concerns relating to compliance will be entered on the local Risk Assurance Framework.
Key findings and learning points from the audit will be submitted to the Clinical Governance Group within the integrated learning report.
Key findings and learning points will be disseminated to relevant staff.
Guideline Management

As an integral part of the knowledge, skills framework, staff are appraised annually to ensure competency in computer skills and the ability to access the current approved guidelines via the Trust's intranet site.

Quarterly memos are sent to line managers to disseminate to their staff the most currently approved guidelines available via the intranet and clinical guideline folders, located in each designated clinical area.
Communication

A quarterly ‘maternity newsletter' is issued to all staff to highlight key changes in clinical practice to include a list of newly approved guidelines for staff to acknowledge and familiarise themselves with and practice accordingly. Midwives that are on maternity leave or ‘bank' staff have letters sent to their home address to update them on current clinical changes.
Approved guidelines are published monthly in the Trust's Staff Focus that is sent via email to all staff.
References

Chantry, C.J., Dewey, K.G., Peerson, J.M., Wagner, E.A., Nommsen-Rivers, L.A., 2014. In-hospital formula use increases early breastfeeding cessation among first-time mothers intending to exclusively breastfeed. Journal of Pediatrics 164(6), pp 1339– 1345
Available at: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4120190/pdf/nihms567814.pdf
Cox S., 2010. An ethical dilemma: should recommending antenatal expressing and storing of colostrum continue? Breastfeeding Review, 18(3), pp 5-7
Cox, S.G., 2006. Expressing and storing colostrum antenatally for use in the newborn period. Breastfeeding Review, 14(3), pp 11-16
East C.E., Dolan W.J., Forster D.A., 2014. Antenatal breast milk expression by women with diabetes for improving infant outcomes. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, 7 (CD010408)
Available at:https://www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD010408.pub2/full

Foster, D.A., et al, 2017. Advising women with diabetes in pregnancy to express breastmilk in late pregnancy (Diabetes and Antenatal Milk Expressing [DAME]): a multicentre, unblinded, randomised controlled trial. The Lancet, 389(10085), pp 2204- 2213
Available at: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140- 6736(17)31373-9/fulltext?elsca1=tlxpr [Accessed on 28/07/19]

Kavanagh, J., et al, 2005. Breast stimulation for cervical ripening and induction of labour. Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, 3 (CD003392) Available at: https://www.cochranelibrary.com/cdsr/doi/10.1002/14651858.CD003392.pub2/full
Martens, P.J., Shafer, L.A., Dean, H.J., et al, 2016. Breastfeeding initiation associated with

reduced incidence of diabetes in mothers and offspring. Obstetrics and Gynecology, 128(5), pp 1095-1104 Available at: https://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/wk/aog/2016/00000128/00000005/art00028 [Accessed on 04/01/19]

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (2006) Postnatal care up to 8 weeks after birth NICE Guideline (CG37) Updated 2015. Available at: https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg37 [Accessed 20 Feb 2018]

The Confidential Enquiry into Maternal and Child health (CEMACH) (2007) Diabetes and Pregnancy: caring for the baby after birth. Findings of a national enquiry: England Wales and Northern Ireland. CEMACH. London

The Confidential Enquiry into Maternal and Child Health (CEMACH) (2005) Pregnancy in women with Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes in 2002-2003 in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. (Diabetes Multidisciplinary Resource) CEMACH. London

Unicef (2017) Guide to the Unicef UK Baby Friendly Initiative Standards. London: Unicef Available at: https://www.unicef.org.uk/babyfriendly/wp- content/uploads/sites/2/2014/02/Guide-to-the-Unicef-UK-Baby-Friendly-Initiative- Standards.pdf
Wambach, K and Riordan, J (2015) Breastfeeding and Human Lactation. 5th edition. Burlington: Jones and Bartlett Learning
